text:
This is what horror games used to be.

author: IHeart16Bit

text: IHeart16Bit Actually, that is what I was thinking of, and I've never played any horror games either except crappy flash games like Exmortis. Just so I have a taste of what you say is what they used to be, what would you guys say is the definitive horror game (regardless of whether or not it's Silent Hill) that makes the most of the style and would be a good one to use as the face of the genre?
author: K.T.B.

text:
@KTBMedia
It's an interesting question, for many the answer will simply be this game, Silent Hill 2. It doesn't rely on cheap spooks (although there are one or two in there, of course), instead it focuses on creating a bleak setting and examining the character's psyche, on a much deeper level than may be apparent initially. 3 also achieves a similar effect with a story coming from a very, very different angle to that of James', but playing the first game (which, again, comes from a very different tone to 2) is essential before playing 3 as it is a direct continuation, where 2 can stand perfectly on it's own.

If you thik you'd enjoy old school point and click games, I Have No Mouth And I Must Scream is a very psychological experience. The "gameplay" is pretty much what you'd expect from such a game, but the story and exploration of it's characters stand out way beyond a regular old game of it's style. I don't find it grabs me in a normal "horror" way, but it definately sticks with you.

There are other great horror games that don't rely on psychological horror to achieve their spooks. For something more on atmosphere and the thrill of survival, the game that does that best for me is the remake of Resident Evil. Put it on a more challenging difficulty and it's a very tense experience. Plus it has a pretty interesting story if you pay attention all the information available to you.

And hey, if you still want to play something hide and seek style (kinda like these modern jump scare only games, only better) take a look at Siren + Blood Curse which nail the atmosphere.

text: Hey everybody - I just released my solo album "Mirror Image" that contains ambient songs (and upbeat songs) heavily inspired by the world of Silent Hill and music of Akira Yamaoka. author: U. Reverie

text: @Akujitsu That's because movies now are all about money, where it is almost impossible for any form of an indie project to break through. As its so money driven any real innovation is killed off. I don't think gaming has quite gone that way yet, and am currently enjoying modern gaming, albeit i still constantly reminisce on what it used to be like. So i definitely agree that gmaes have overtaken film as an artform.
author: Luke Marshall

text:
@Akujitsu  but that's almost worse.  Dragoon's soundtrack is depressingly mediocre.  It's battle music is awful, along with it's unfitting "alternate" battle music that sounds like elevator music.  And the rest of the soundtrack isn't much better.

At least put Ocarina of Time, Super Metroid, and Secret of mana on such a list before you put Dragoon...
